workshops so um before we get into the details i wanted to provide some
context and a high level overview of first what kubernetes is for uh whatever uh for if you're not
familiar with the system and then talk a bit about eks as a managed service so kubernetes
is an open source system for automating deployment scaling and management of your containerized application
um allows you basically to um orchestrate the deployment and run your application
on scale allowing you to focus on the actual content of your application not really about the infrastructure behind
it so everything is defined in a declarative way um you create your cluster and then you
worry about the code and the services and the pods and will getting a bit of the terminology during
the workshop as well the good things is that uh since it's based on container technology allows your developer to
work on it locally on their laptop uh deploy their services or their applications and then run
anywhere um doesn't matter if it's running on their machine or on the cloud or on-premise it's also
very easy to manage that new functionality because it's based on the concept of pods which is a collection of containers
and services that run on your cluster allowing you to add and remove services
and use these components to basically build use those as a building blocks to
expand and improve the functionality of your application also allows you to iterate quickly
and again not be constrained from the actual underlying hardware either it be virtual or
actually physical hardware and the thing is that as with everything it still requires a
bit of management you still need to create your cluster and that's one of the reason why we came
with and launched amazon elastic container service for kubernetes um and it's a basically fully managed
kubernetes services um it runs upstream kubernetes and it's certified kubernetes
so you can leverage all the benefits that you would normally have by running your own cluster so you don't have to
worry about compatibility or you don't have to worry about support for uh tooling from third party
community you can easily migrate what you're using right now onto aks
with no problem at all since it's fully compliant the other nice benefit is that uh deeply
integrated with all uh our uh services such as cloud watch autoscaling um iam and virtual private cloud
allowing you to benefit from those services and the functionality of those services in a transparent way without having to
bring in third party plugins or trying to orchestrate these from your actual cluster the other nice
thing is that it takes care of the control plane i will get that in a second but you can also decide to uh use it on
the aws far gate which is our um serverless container solution where you don't
even have to worry about where your resources are running so you don't even have to worry about the nodes where your
actual container will be running for the purpose of the demo we're going to use amazon ec2
so that gives you a better understanding on how everything works behind the scenes and how you can manage your own nodes as well
but ideally you can decide if you want to have a complete hands-off
experience with your cluster and have everything been managed by by aws so um one thing that i wanted
to expand a bit is what exactly we mean by um a managed service so what are we
managing and what the customer is responsible for bringing to uh the the cluster um normally
when you want to run a kubernetes cluster you have to worry about a couple of things uh the first one is about your
controller so the controllers would uh take action on your cluster decides where the container or pods needs to be
deployed if they need to be replaced to check about the health of the status and the desired state of the cluster
and you also have to think about where all the information is going to be stored so etc uh it's a master uh distributed key
value store where you are going to store um all so where the kubernetes is going to store all the
information about the cluster itself so what's the status um what is the desired state
what are the variables and configuration that you are creating in the cluster with and so on
normally when you're planning your cluster you need to think very carefully about this
portion of the um the cluster itself because depending on the size of your cluster you might
want either bigger nodes or multiple nodes for a high availability and fault tolerance
um when using eks all of these is managed by aws so you don't have to think about
either the sizing of your controllers you don't have to think about high availability it's all taken care
by aws and we also will scale these transparently as your workers are
growing or your cluster is growing in size um so you're just responsible for
managing your worker nodes where your pods are going to run and in case using fargate um you don't
even have to manage those workers nodes so this is what we mean by managed service the nice
thing is that um we said it's highly available and what do we mean by that is that you will have
a controller at least one controller in every availability zone so that in case something happens the
single node remember uh always designed for failure uh you still have other controllers available and
again this is completely automatic and transparent um and you connect to these um
the controller cluster through a network interface that is going to be provisioned in your vpc
it's single tenant so you are not sharing the cluster with anyone and they will just do uh whatever you wanted to
do and that we said it's fully compliant with the uh upstream kubernetes so there's no feature that you're
renouncing or no thing that you cannot have with a normally
owned cluster or a cluster that you're provisioning by yourself you can interact with it through the console or the regular api clients
such as the eks ctl or even the other base command line that will allow you to provision um the
cluster and then manage it as you would manage a regular cluster uh so you don't even have to tell your
developers uh to change tooling when moving to uh eks
we also have a cluster of etcd nodes uh that would be using for the
storage and those are not exposed directly to the customer but the api server so the controller
servers will use those through a load balancer inside the eks control plane so the idea
is that um having a managed service removes a lot of the moving components
you have to uh do less heavy lifting with managing the cluster and we take a
care of a lot of things that you should put seriously when deploying a kubernetes cluster for high ability and
for um the uh resilience of your cluster and the scalability of your cluster itself
allowing you to focus more on the application so further enhancing the core concepts of kubernetes
